Sigma notation

As stated above, a series is a sum of a long list of numbers (i.e. the sum of entries of a sequence). So for example \[ 1+2+3+4+\cdots \qquad \mbox{and} \qquad 4 + 8 + 12 + 16 + 24 \] are both series. The first series is infinite but the second has only five terms. We can see that writing a series like this is cumbersome (and in the case of infinite series impossible). Fortunately a series can be represented in a compact manner using sigma notation. This refers to the fact that the Greek capital letter sigma (written \(\sum\)) is used to represent the series. Let us consider the second series above as an example.


Example

Write the series \(4 + 8 + 12 + 16 + 24\) using sigma notation and therefore find the value of the sum.

Solution

We can write the given series as \[ \sum\limits_{n=1}^6 4n. \] This expression is read as "the terms of the series are given by the formula \(4n\) as \(n\) goes from \(1\) to \(6\)". The variable \(n\) is called the index of the summation. The bottom of the sigma tells us that the first value of \(n\) is a \(1\), the top of the sigma tells us the last value of \(n\) to substitute into the formula.

To generate the terms of a series given in sigma notation, we successively replace the index of summation with consecutive integers from the first value to the last value of the index. S in this case we must replace \(n\) in the formula by \(1,2,3,4,5,6\) and them sum each term. Hence we have \[ \sum\limits_{n=1}^6 4n = 4(1) + 4(2) + 4(3) + 4(4) + 4(5) + 4(6) = 4 + 8 + 12 + 16 + 20 + 24 = 84. \] So the sum of the series is \(84\).


As we will see in a later section, one of the advantages of sigma notation is that it allows us to deal with infinite series as well. We formally define these ideas as follows.


Given a function \(f\) and two integers \(A\) and \(B\) (with \(A\leq B\)), we write \[   \sum_{n=A}^B f(n) = f(A) + f(A+1) + \cdots + f(B), \] i.e. adding up the results when \(f\) is applied to each of the integers from \(A\) to \(B\).

Note that we don't have to use the letter \(n\) for the counter; other common choices are \(i,j,k\) and \(m\).
